Author: thorax
Content:
I can only imagine this is taking advantage of the fact that Windows task scheduling gives higher priority to threads which are currently receiving user interaction.

In certain cases, doing this would allow the process to handle returning data faster, especially if it was having to communicate with Excel a great deal and there was a lot of context-switching/waiting between the processes and you wanted to favor Excel's processing of the returned data over a background task with high CPU usage.

Perhaps the problem is that pieces of the Excel side were timing-out and causing all the returned data to be lost.

To read more about UI thread boosting in Windows, this article is a pretty good one:\nhttp://www.sriramkrishnan.com/blog/2006/08/tale-of-two-sched...

Author: bokonist
Content:
Avoid comments about naivety and instead focus on the actual content at hand. Exhibit the maturity that your writing and education seem to indicate.

The internet is an autistic medium. When you called my views "dangerous", I thought you were taking the discussion a little too seriously, so I responded with a playful retort (notice the wink). Obviously, the humor was lost in transmission.

Regardless, I am not organizing any kind of rebellion. This is simply a fun intellectual tussle. When I start gathering troops on the moons of Yavin IV, we can talk about dangerous.

Anyway, Powers is enough by himself to disprove your assertion about academic research as garbage.

I already acknowledged in a previous comment that there was some good stuff coming out of the university. It's just mostly garbage in the humanities. It's a high enough ratio of garbage to fully justify the "The anti-college bias in the hacker community" that you originally complained about.

(2) Taken as a whole, the research from all departments in our university system is valuable. It seems that we are primarily addressing (2) here.

The relevant questions as I see it are:

1) Does the average student have a net increase to his knowledge from attending the university?

2) If yes, is there a net increase from the classes and school work?

3) If yes to 2), is the net increase greater than what the student would otherwise be doing.

4) If yes to 3), is it worth the money?

5) Is a university education worth subsidization from the government?

6) Is the net output of university research a net positive?

7) Is the research worth subsidization from the government?

8) If no to 5), should the university be actually disestablished- ie, all ties between it and the government cut off?

My answers:

1) Debatable. Some courses are quite good, especially in the sciences. But there are a number of courses that are actually destructive of knowledge. In several of the fields I know very well - sociology, economics, and architecture - the main output of the courses seems to be elaborate lessons on why 1 + 1 is 3, and why ugliness is beautiful and beauty is ugly. I actually think the net effect of architecture education in particular is actually negative.

2) Most of my learning in college came from clubs, other students, and independent reading. The net effect of classroom education is probably negative for most people.

3) In my case, I have learned way more outside of the classroom than in it. The benefit of the college years was lots of free time.

4) Unless you are rich, it's not worth paying sticker price for a private college. The price of a public college is not much greater than the cost of living in a city, so you should probably go just because it's a lot of fun. But you should rely on yourself and peers for actually learning, not classes.

5) I'd say absolutely not.

6) In some of the sciences the output is definitely a net positive. In the social sciences, law, architecture definitely not. Those fields have done incredible damage. In literature or history, well, it's about 99% garbage with 1% guys like Powers, David Fischer or Bryan Ward-Perkins. So I guess that's a net positive, if only because bad literature doesn't harm anyone, you can just ignore it.

7) Outside the scientific fields, no. There is simply not enough good output to justify the hundreds of billions of dollars that universities receive.

8) I am a disestablishmentarian - especially with regards to the humanities. The government should not be in the business of telling its subjects what to think. There should be no subsidies. All credentialing laws requiring a degree to perform a profession should be revoked. All laws that allocate funds based on holding a PHD or institutional affiliation should be revoked. Universities should lose their non-profit status and be taxed like everyone else.

I encourage you to read about some of the research being done here, and I'd be interested to know how it fits in with your preconceived notions.

Well, there seems to be no way for me to actually view the output of the project. So until I can see the results, or see evidence of someone outside the university enjoying the results, it does indeed fit my notions that most academic work seems to be produced for the benefit of those producing it, with little contribution to society as a whole.

Author: jfarmer
Content:
I'm going to toot my own horn an link to an article I wrote six months ago: http://20bits.com/articles/the-099-app-store/

It's the same fundamental misunderstanding. It's like launching a Facebook app and hoping the app directory helps you take off (in the early days there were people who did just this), or banking on getting mentioned on TechCrunch.

Now, I don't know what Rick Strom did or didn't do to market his apps, but success or failure isn't the App Store's fault. It removes a huge chunk of friction from the sales funnel, but it's all at the final, transactional step.

There's a big chunk in the middle which consists of marketing and, AFAIK, no app developer has talked extensively about their marketing efforts, only about their position in the App Store.

Rick is right: you're probably going to lose that game. Rather than go home I'd try to figure out a better game to play.

Author: ja2ke
Content:
Why would someone want to copy the native OS UI for a web app? That will just make people think your app is poorly made, when the controls look identical to those from their mobile device's native OS, but function in a hobbled-via-Webkit-limitations manner.

Making something aesthetically ... harmonic ... with the native UI is fine, probably encouraged, but don't set you and your users up for disappointment and frustration by replicating the aesthetics of controls you can't replicate functionally.

Author: sounddust
Content: You still can't name a file or folder "con" (even in Win7) because it's a reserved word used for keyboard input on the command line.   When Windows 9x was popular, you could bluescreen any machine on a local network by trying to access the share \\machinename\con\con, which was great if you lived in a dorm :)

Author: edw519
Content:
This reminds me of the first pg essay I ever read, "Good and Bad Procrastination," which also references Richard Hamming. This essay directed me to his site, and eventually here.

http://paulgraham.com/procrastination.html

I like pg's treatment a little more. He distills it down to one sentence, "What's the best thing you could be working on, and why aren't you?"

This single sentence has pretty much directed much of my work since then. It's so simple it's almost counter-intuitive. I have designed systems to sort "problems" by descending value and taught my users to just work on #1 until it's fixed. But it wasn't until reading pg's corollary to Hamming's work that I did it myself.

Thanks for reminding me.

Author: grandalf
Content:
This is an insightful post. Sometimes people let themselves off the hook.

Defining which problem is the "most important" is a bit tough, but whatever problem you are working on ought to be very important to you.

So in a sense, the point is to avoid just working for a paycheck and try to do something that means something to you.

Author: zimbabwe
Content:
If you're looking for design, ilovetypography and SmashingMag.

If you're looking for "general art", you're dealing with an incredibly tough subject, because each specific field of art requires just as much focus as the field of computer programming. There are few similarities in technique between composing and popular songwriting and rap, for instance, in the field of music alone. Oil painting and photography and sculpting and weaving are all drastically different. So the only depth you could get on a general art site would be something like "Look at such-and-such pretty thing," unless it was very cleverly designed to allow for more in-depth conversation. Then you'd have to convince those sorts of people to use the site, and some varieties of artists almost routinely avoid the Internet.

Hacker News works because programming is very online-intensive as-is. Art isn't. Making the transition is very hard. I should know: I've made three attempts thus far.

Author: derefr
Content:
Yes, I would "accept" that—as a theoretical explanation. However, as a pure-determinist, I would also accept that people would be offended be her incivility, as their social mores would tell them to be in response. Likewise, rape is an evolutionary urge—but so is the urge to punish people for it, or prevent people from doing it.

To simplify: there is no need to apologize for your urge to punch someone you don't like in the face. There is no need for them to apologize for defending themselves, or calling the police. Both make subjective sense. Apologies are for when you were wrong given your own perspective.

Author: camtarn
Content:
Unfortunately, JSLint objects strongly to using 'new foo()' without assigning the result to anything, which is a pain if you're using Prototype AJAX since firing off an AJAX request is done by calling 'new Ajax.Request(url, options)'. The only way to get around this seems to be to put parentheses around the statement - there's no way to turn most individual checks on or off, unlike other static analysis tools I've used like PMD and FindBugs.

I still use it - because that trailing-comma-in-hash-definition issue in IE is really annoying.

Author: bk
Title: Ask HN: How to keep my data, apps, config movable between computers
Content:
I want to be able to move my setup (data, apps, config) as effortlessly as possible between physical hardware.

For example, I want to be able to move from a broken machine to a new one without disruption (reinstalling, reconfiguring, moving data).

Do you have a setup or solution to achieve this sort of freedom from hardware (and OS to some extent).

How easy is it to have a linux/windows/(os x) install that can flexibly run on completely different hardware (different graphics cards, networking, etc.)?

Ideas:

- Use a VM player to run everything and back up the image so that for any new machine the only thing to install is the VM player.

- Boot from USB: Limited size/speed/writes. External HD: limited portability. Both: Can OS handle different hardware components on changing "host" machines?

- Avoid platform lock-in. Use cross-platform applications (e.g. Thunderbird) that allow switching OS if necessary.

Is anyone doing something like this? What's your setup/solution?

PS: Background - I'm looking to buy a new laptop and I don't find one for my budget that I like, so I'd go for the cheapest one now and migrate when a better option that I really like comes along. I don't want to reinstall/configure everything every time I move computers.

Author: lux
Title: PubMail, a newsletter app for messagepub.com
Content:
I'm a developer as well as a songwriter/performer, and I needed something reliable for sending out my artist newsletter. I could have done all the DNS/SPF/DKIM stuff myself, but it seems like that's still an uphill battle with ISPs that most of the advice on here warns against.

The problem is as a musician, I can't afford the $5 + $0.01/email that services like campaignmonitor.com charge, at least not once my newsletter grows in size. messagepub.com's $0.0015/email was much more up my alley.

Knowing that many startups are in the same position (mine sure is! ;), I thought I should announce the app here as well in case other startups find it useful too. It's written in PHP5 + Sqlite because most shared hosts support it, so more artists would be able to use it, but that may make it a little less compatible with some startups. But anyway, here it is:

http://www.johnnybroadway.com/id.3/title.introducing-pubmail-artist-newsletters-on-the-cheap

Any feedback is always appreciated too!
